Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Understanding the environment-to-epigenetic alterations driving ecosystem function and resilience under continuing climate change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The research aims to understand how organisms respond to changes in their environment. This is important for accurately predicting the effects of a changing climate. This project will investigate how the sea urchin, Diadema antillarum, responds to warming temperatures. These sea urchins play a vital role in Caribbean coral reef ecosystems, which are severely threatened by environmental change. The research will contribute to the management and conservation of coral reef ecosystems that generate essential ecosystem services to people (e.g., fisheries, recreation, tourism, and protection from tropical storms). Additionally, the Fellow will increase the inclusion of underrepresented groups in biology by mentoring students and providing educational outreach activities at institutions that serve historically underrepresented racial minorities.

This research investigates the role of epigenetic processes in providing rapid phenotypic plasticity under changing environmental conditions. The project assesses epigenetic patterns and their connection to varying genotypes, demography, and physiological responses (e.g., righting ability), in sea urchins inhabiting areas that naturally differ in their temperature regimes. A reciprocal transplant experiment will be used to distinguish between local adaptation and acclimation processes, followed by spawning and crossing of adult urchins to investigate the persistence of epigenetic marks across generations. Genome-wide differences in DNA methylation, body size, and thermal tolerance will be compared across larvae that differ in their developmental and parental thermal history exposure. The project will also generate a draft genome for Diadema antillarum. The Fellow will mentor students at Florida International University and the University of Puerto Rico. Additionally, the Fellow will provide educational outreach activities to high school students and their families at a South Florida public high school, the Marine Academy of Science and Technology at Florida International Universityâ€™s Biscayne Bay Campus. Public outreach will also be performed in Puerto Rico with the Sociedad Ambiente Marino conservation organization that will include events in which participants actively interact with the study organism to connect its importance to coral reefs and the value that coral reef ecosystems provide to people.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the effects of an extensive die-off of a keystone species in Caribbean coral reef ecosystems. The long-spined sea urchin, Diadema antillarum, feeds upon macroalgae that are in competition with corals; the presence of D. antillarum has been shown to improve coral health and ecosystem function of coral reefs. Unfortunately, a mass mortality event led to widespread losses of D. antillarum in 2022, including within coastal areas of Puerto Rico. The mortalities are believed to have been caused by the spread of a pathogenic scuticociliate (Hewson et al. 2023). Prior to death, infected individuals exhibited limited movement, loss of spines, and loss of epidermal tissues.

A major outcome that was generated as part of this project was a genome assembly for D. antillarum; it is the first reference level nuclear genome assembly for this species. This represents a valuable molecular resource that will contribute to future research within this and other disciplinary fields.

Findings that detail how the mortality event impacted sea urchin densities are important for restoration practitioners; results from this work have been disseminated to community partners at Sociedad Ambiente Marino, a non-profit, community-based reef restoration organization in Puerto Rico. Densities of grossly normal (i.e., apparently healthy, asymptomatic), grossly abnormal (i.e., apparently infected, symptomatic), and dead urchins were assessed at four study sites in Puerto Rico. Sea urchins were observed immediately prior to, during, one month after, and one year after the mortality event. High numbers of grossly abnormal and dead urchins were observed during the mortality event. Sea urchin densities in some locations declined by as much as 92% between May and June 2022. Densities recorded approximately one year after the event (May 2023) indicated slow to moderate recovery of D. antillarum populations at these sites.

Tissue samples were collected from grossly normal and abnormal sea urchins during different stages of the mortality event. Total DNA isolated from these tissues was analyzed to identify DNA that belonged to the scuticociliate pathogen. This was performed using droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) technology, which provided a highly accurate approach to quantify levels of infection within the sea urchins. Overall, the pathogen was either absent or found at very low levels within the tissues of grossly normal urchins. Some grossly normal urchins that were sampled immediately prior to or during the mortality event had slightly higher pathogen levels, indicating that they may have been at an early stage of infection. In contrast, grossly abnormal urchins had significantly greater pathogen levels, in some cases, nearly 95,000 times more than those found in grossly normal urchins.

The physiological conditions of grossly normal and abnormal sea urchins were assessed during different stages of the mortality event. The amount of time it takes for a sea urchin to right itself (i.e., return to a normal position after being flipped upside down) is important for avoiding predation and is a useful metric for assessing whether the urchins are in good physiological condition. Among grossly normal urchins, righting ability was not significantly affected by time (i.e., during different stages of the mortality event). Righting ability of grossly normal urchins also did not differ between those that were not infected and those with low infection levels detected in their tissues. However, grossly abnormal urchins, all of whom were found to have high levels of the pathogen in their tissues, were not capable of exhibiting a righting response. This indicates that the pathogen appears to impact the water vascular systems of the sea urchins, which are needed to successfully regulate and control their movement. Predators were regularly observed feeding upon grossly abnormal D. antillarum; infection appears to inhibit their ability to move and defend themselves from predation.

Gene expression data was generated for 105 samples collected at different sites and during different stages of the mortality event. These included sea urchins of varying health status (i.e., grossly normal/symptomatic, grossly abnormal/symptomatic), with varying righting response times, and with varying infection levels as quantified via ddPCR assays. These data will be analyzed using the genome generated from this project and will provide important insight into the molecular-level responses of these urchins to the pathogen and molecular patterns expressed during their recovery.

This project also aimed to increase the inclusion of underrepresented groups in biology via student mentoring and engagement in educational outreach activities. Specific outcomes included the training and mentorship of undergraduate and Ph.D. students in scientific writing, field methods, and laboratory approaches. Short educational videos were also created and are available in both English and Spanish to increase their accessibility. This project helped to inform and secure funds for ongoing work supported by Puerto Rico Sea Grant. This supports continued research that build from the objectives of the reported project and provides additional mentoring/training of students underrepresented in biology.
